24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything26:T22ee,<entryFree id="n14368" key="رَبٌّ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رَبٌّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A lord, a possessor, an owner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a proprietor,</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">مَالِكٌ</foreign>, (T, IAmb, S, M, A, Msb, K,) of a thing, (T,) of anything, (S, M, A, K,) or of an irrational thing; (Msb;) <hi rend="ital">a person who has a right,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">just title</hi> or <hi rend="ital">claim, to the possession</hi> of anything; or its <foreign lang="ar">صَاحِب</foreign> [which is syn. with <foreign lang="ar">مَالِك</foreign>]; (M, A, K;) <foreign lang="ar">رَبٌّ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مَالِكٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">صَاحِبٌ</foreign> all signifying in Pers. <foreign lang="ar">خُدَاوَنْد</foreign>: (KL:) and <hi rend="ital">a lord, master,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chief;</hi> (Msb, TA;) or <hi rend="ital">a lord, master,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chief, to whom obedience is paid:</hi> (IAmb, TA:) and <hi rend="ital">a lord, ruler, governor, regulator,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disposer;</hi> (TA;) <hi rend="ital">an orderer, a rectifier,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a reformer:</hi> (IAmb, TA:) <hi rend="ital">a rearer, fosterer, bringer-up, feeder,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nourisher:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a completer,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an accomplisher:</hi> (TA:) it is an epithet, like <foreign lang="ar">نَمٌّ</foreign> from <foreign lang="ar">نَمَّ</foreign>: or an inf. n. used as an intensive epithet; like <foreign lang="ar">عَدْلٌ</foreign>; (Ksh and Bd * in i. l;) originally signifying the “ bringing (a thing) to a state of completion by degrees;” (Bd, ibid.;) then used in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">مَالِكٌ</foreign>: (Ksh and Bd ibid.:) the pl. [of pauc.] is <foreign lang="ar">أَرْبَابٌ</foreign> and [of mult.] <foreign lang="ar">رُبُوبٌ</foreign>, (M, K,) and accord. to Sh, <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابٌ</foreign> also, (TA,) signifying <foreign lang="ar">أَصْحَابٌ</foreign>, (K,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14368-1" target="رَبُوبٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14379"/></foreign> is app. a quasi-pl. n.: (M:) the fem. is   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14368-2" target="رَبَّةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14371"/></foreign>; of which the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّاتٌ</foreign>. (T.) Whoever possesses a thing is its <foreign lang="ar">رَبّ</foreign>: you say, <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ رَبُّ الدَّابَّةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He is the possessor,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">owner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">master, of the beast</hi>], and <foreign lang="ar">الدَّارِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">of the house</hi>], (T,) and <foreign lang="ar">المَالِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">of the property,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cattle</hi>]; (Msb;) and <foreign lang="ar">هِىَ <ref cref="n14368-3" target="رَبَّةُ" n="3" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>البَيْتِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">She is the owner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mistress, of the house</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tent</hi>]. (T.) With the article <foreign lang="ar">ال</foreign>, it is [properly] applied only to <hi rend="ital">God:</hi> (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) He is <foreign lang="ar">رَبُّ الأَرْبَابِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The Lord of lords</hi>]. (T. [Thus the pl. with the article <foreign lang="ar">ال</foreign> is applied to created beings.]) To any other being it is not [properly] applied but as a prefixed noun governing another noun as its complement in the gen. case [or in a similar manner]. (S.) The pagan Arabs, however, sometimes applied it to A <hi rend="ital">king,</hi> (S,) or to a <hi rend="ital">lord</hi> as meaning a <hi rend="ital">master</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chief:</hi> (Msb:) El- Hárith says, (S, Msb,) i. e. Ibn-Hillizeh, (S,) <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَهُوَ الرَّبُّ وَالشَّهِيدُ عَلَى يُوْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">مِ الحِيَارَيْنِ وَالبَلَآءُ بَلَآءُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> (S, Msb,) i. e. <hi rend="ital">And he</hi> (meaning El-Mundhir Ibn-Má-es-Semà, or, as some say, 'Amr Ibn-Hind,) <hi rend="ital">was the king</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">lord</hi>] <hi rend="ital">and witness of</hi> our fighting on <hi rend="ital">the day of El-Hiyárán</hi> (the name of a place), <hi rend="ital">and the trial was a</hi> hard <hi rend="ital">trial.</hi> (EM, p. 285: [in which <foreign lang="ar">الحَيَارَيْنِ</foreign> is erroneously put for <foreign lang="ar">الحِيَارَيْنِ</foreign>.]) Some forbid that a man should be called the <foreign lang="ar">رَبّ</foreign> of his slave: (Msb:) it is said in a trad. that the slave shall not say to his master, <foreign lang="ar">رَبّى</foreign>, because it is like attributing a partner to God: (TA:) but <foreign lang="ar">رَبّ</foreign> is sometimes used in the sense of <hi rend="ital">lord</hi> as meaning <hi rend="ital">master</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chief</hi> prefixed to a noun signifying a rational being governed by it in the gen. case: thus in the saying of the Prophet, <foreign lang="ar">حَتَّى تَلِدَ الأَمَةُ رَبَّهَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">So that the female slave shall bring forth</hi> him who will become <hi rend="ital">her master</hi>], or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14368-4" target="رَبَّتَهَا" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> [<hi rend="ital">her mistress</hi>], accord. to different transmitters; (Msb;) relating to the signs of the hour of resurrection: i. e., the female slave shall bring forth to her master a child that shall be as a master [or mistress] to her because like his [or her] father in rank: meaning that captives and concubines shall be numerous. (TA.) As to the phrase in the Kur [xii. 42], <foreign lang="ar">اُذْكُرْنِى عِنْدَ رَبِّكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Mention thou me in the presence of thy lord</hi>], Joseph thus addressed his fellow-prisoner agreeably with the acceptation in which he [the latter] understood the words. (TA.) A similar instance also occurs in the same chapter, in the verse immediately preceding. (Msb.) In another verse, [23 of the same ch.,] <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّهُ رَبِّى</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Verily he is my lord</hi>] may refer to Joseph's master or to God. (M, TA.) The words of the Kur [lxxxix. 28 and 29], <foreign lang="ar">اِرْجِعِى إِلَى رَبِّكِ رَاضِيَةً</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَرْضِيَّةً فَٱدْخُلِى فِى عَبْدىِ</foreign>, as some read, [instead of <foreign lang="ar">عِبَادِى</foreign>,] may mean <hi rend="ital">Return to thine owner,</hi> [<hi rend="ital">approving, approved,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">and enter into my servant.</hi> (M, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Without the article <foreign lang="ar">ال</foreign>, as some say, (L, TA,) it is sometimes written and pronounced   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14368-5" target="رَبٌ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14367"/></foreign>, without teshdeed; (L, K;) as in the following verse, cited by El-Mufaddal, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَقَدْ عَلِمَ الأَقْوَامُ أَنْ لَيْسَ فَوْقَهُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">رَبٌ غَيْرُ مَنْ يَعْطِى الحُظُوظَ وَيَرْزُقُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">And the peoples have known that there is not above him a lord beside Him who gives the portions</hi> of mankind and of others <hi rend="ital">and grants the means of subsistence</hi>]. (L.) And Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] mentions the phrase <foreign lang="ar">لَا وَرَبِيكَ لَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَفْعَلُ</foreign>, for <foreign lang="ar">لَا وَرَبِّكَ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">No, by thy Lord, I will not do</hi> such a thing]; the [latter] <foreign lang="ar">ب</foreign> being changed into <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> because of the reduplication. (M, K: * in the CK <foreign lang="ar">رَبْيِكَ</foreign>.)    </entryFree>27:T452a,<entryFree id="n14369" key="رُبَّ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رُبَّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> is a word of which there are seventy dial. vars., all mentioned by Zekereeyà El-Ansáree in his great Expos. of the “ Munferijeh, ” but only eighteen of which are mentioned in the K, including some that are formed with the affix <foreign lang="ar">ت</foreign>, some with the affix <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign>, and some with both these affixes together; as follows: (TA:) <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign> (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K, &amp;c.) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّ</foreign> (T, M, Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّ</foreign>, (Mughnee,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-1" target="رُبَ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14366"/></foreign> (T, S, M, Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَ</foreign> (T, M, Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْ</foreign> (Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْ</foreign>; (Mughnee;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-2" target="رُبَّتَ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14386"/></foreign> (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتَ</foreign> (M, Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبُّت</foreign> (TA) <pb n="1004"/> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّتْ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتْ</foreign> (Mughnee) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتْ</foreign>, (TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-3" target="رُبَتَ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14375"/></foreign> (T, Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتَ</foreign> (Mughnee, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْتَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْتَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبُتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْتِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْتِ</foreign> (TA) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَتْ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتْ</foreign> (Mughnee) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتْ</foreign>; (TA;) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّمَا</foreign> (T, S, M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّمَا</foreign> (M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّمَا</foreign>, (TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-4" target="رُبَمَا" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> (T, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَمَا</foreign> (K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْمَا</foreign>; (TA;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-5" target="رُبَّتَمَا" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> (T, S, M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتَمَا</foreign> (M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتَمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّتْمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتْمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُّتْمَا</foreign>, (TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-6" target="رُبَتَمَا" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتَمَا</foreign> (M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتَمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْتَمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْتَمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبْتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبْتُمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَتْمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رَبَتْمَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبُتْمَا</foreign>: (TA:) [of all these, the most common are <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّمَا</foreign>: and]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-7" target="رُبَّتَ" n="7" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14386"/></foreign> is the most common of the forms that have the affix <foreign lang="ar">ت</foreign>: (Mughnee and K on the letter <foreign lang="ar">ت</foreign>:) and the forms with teshdeed are more common than the [corresponding] forms without teshdeed. (M.) It is a word, (M,) or particle, (T, S, Mughnee, K,) governing the gen. case: (S, M, Mughnee, K:) or a noun, (K, TA,) [i. e. an indecl. noun,] in the opinion of the Koofees and some others; but this opinion is rejected by Ibn-Málik in the Tesheel and its Expos., and by AHei, and by IHsh in the Mughnee. (TA.) Accord. to some, (K, TA,) it is used to denote a small number, (T, M, Msb, K, TA,) always, (TA,) or mostly: (Msb, TA:) [thus it may be rendered <hi rend="ital">Few</hi> if we render the noun following it as a pl.; and <hi rend="ital">scarce any</hi> if we render the noun following as a sing. or a pl.:] it is the <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">كَمْ</foreign> when this latter is not used interrogatively: (T:) [and with <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> affixed, restricting it from government, it may be rendered <hi rend="ital">Few times,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">seldom:</hi>] or it is used to denote a large number; (K, TA;) i. e. always: so says IDrst: (TA:) [thus used, but such is not always the case, it may be rendered <hi rend="ital">Many,</hi> whether we render the noun following it as a sing. or as a pl.: and with <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> affixed, <hi rend="ital">Many times, many a time, oftentimes, ofttimes, often,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">frequently:</hi>] or it is used to denote a small and a large number; (Mughnee, K;) often the latter, and seldom the former: (Mughnee:) or it is used in a case of boasting, or glorying, (K, TA,) exclusively of other cases, (TA,) to denote a large number: (K, TA:) or it does not denote by itself either a small number or a large number; but one or the other of these meanings is inferred from the context: (K:) [but sometimes neither of these meanings can be clearly inferred from the context: in these cases, it may be rendered <hi rend="ital">Some:</hi> and with <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> affixed, <hi rend="ital">Sometimes:</hi>] accord. to Er-Radee, its primary meaning is to denote a small number, but it has been so much used to denote a large number as to be in this latter sense as though it were proper, and in the former sense as though it were tropical, requiring context [to explain it]. (Marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee.) [Without the affix <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign>,] it governs an indeterminate noun (T, * S, Msb, Mughnee, K) only, (T, S, K,) and a pronoun. (S, M, Mughnee.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ يَوْمٍ بَكَّرْتُ فِيهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Few,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">many, days have I gone forth early therein</hi>]: (T:) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ رَجُلٍ قَائِمٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Few,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">many, men are standing</hi>]: (M:) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ رَجُلٍ قَامَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Few,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">many, men stood</hi>]: (Msb:) and in like manner, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14369-8" target="رُبَّتَ" n="8" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n14386"/>رَجُلٍ</foreign>; (Msb;) for the <foreign lang="ar">ت</foreign> in this case is not a denotative of the fem. gender. (Msb.) The pronoun affixed to it is of the third pers., (S, M,) and is [generally] sing. and masc., (S, Mughnee,) though it may be followed by a fem. and by a dual and by a pl.: (S:) notwithstanding its being determinate in the utmost degree, its use in this manner is allowable because it resembles an indeterminate noun in its being used without the previous mention of the noun to which it relates; and hence it requires a noun to explain it: (IJ, M:) it annuls the government of <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign>; (TA;) and the indeterminate noun that follows it is put in the accus. case as a specificative: (S, Mughnee:) thus you say, <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهُ رَجُلًا قَدْ ضَرَبْتُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Few,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">many, men I have beaten</hi>]: (S, M: *) but accord. to the Koofees, you say <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهُ رَجُلًا</foreign>, (S,) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهَا ٱمْرَأَةً</foreign>, (M,) and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهُمَا رَجُلَيْنش</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهُمْ رِجَالًا</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهُنَّ نِسَآءً</foreign>: he who puts the pronoun in the sing. [in all cases] holds it to be allusive to something unknown; and he who does not put it in the sing. [when it is not followed by a sing. noun] holds it to be used in reply to a question, as though it were said to a man, “ Hast thou not any young women? ” and he answered, <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّهُنَّ جَوَارٍ قَدْ مَلَكْتُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Few,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">many, young women have I possessed</hi>]: Ibn-Es-Sarráj says that the grammarians are as though they were of one consent in holding <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign> to be a replicative [app. meaning in a case of this kind, with an affixed pronoun]: (S:) [but it is not always a replicative in a case of this kind; though perhaps it was originally:] AHeyth cites as an ex. <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَرُبَّهُ عَطِبًا أَنْقَذْتُ مِ العَطَبِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">And many a perishing</hi> man <hi rend="ital">have I saved from perdition</hi>]. (TA. [But the reading commonly found in grammars is <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ عَطَبِهْ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">from his state of perdition.</hi>]) The following is an ex. of the use of <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign> to denote a small number, [or rather to denote singleness,] <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">أَلَا رُبَّ مَوْلُودٍ وَلَيْسَ لَهُ أَبٌ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَذِى وَلَدٍ لَمْ يَلْدِهِ أَبَوَانِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Now surely scarce an instance is there of anyone born not having a father, and of anyone having offspring whom two parents have not procreated</hi>]; meaning [our Lord] Jesus and Adam: (Mughnee: [but I have substituted <foreign lang="ar">يَلْدِهِ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">يَلْدَهُ</foreign>, the reading in my copy of that work: <foreign lang="ar">لَمْ يَلْدِهِ</foreign> is for <foreign lang="ar">لَمْ يَلِدْهُ</foreign>, for the sake of the metre; like as <foreign lang="ar">لِمْ أَجْدِ</foreign> is for <foreign lang="ar">لَمْ أَجِدْ</foreign>:]) and among the many exs. of its use to denote a large number, is the saying, in a trad., <foreign lang="ar">يَا رُبَّ كاَسِيَةٍ فِى الدُّنْيَا عَارِيَةٌ يَوْمَ القِيٰمَةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">O, many a female having clothing in the present state of existence</hi> will be <hi rend="ital">naked on the day of resurrection!</hi>]; and the saying of an Arab of the desert, after the ending of Ramadán, <foreign lang="ar">يَا رُبَّ صَائِمِهِ لَنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يَعصُومَهُ وَيَا رُبَّ قَائِمِهِ لَنْ يَقُومَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">O, many a keeper of its fast shall not keep its fast</hi> again! <hi rend="ital">and O, many a passer of its nights in prayer,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">per-</hi> 
                  <hi rend="ital">former of its</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَرَاوِيح</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">shall not pass its nights in prayer,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perform its</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تراويح</foreign>, again!]. (Mughnee.) [But in this last ex., and in others, it relates to few in comparison with others, though many abstractedly.]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> is affixed to <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign> &amp;c. in order that a verb may follow it; (S, Mughnee;) and the verb that follows it is generally a preterite, (T, Mughnee,) as to the letter and the meaning: (Mughnee:) you say, <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّمَا جَآءَنِى فُلَانٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Seldom,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">often, such a one came to me,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">has come to me</hi>]: (T:) sometimes the verb is a future; (T, Mughnee;) but only when it expresses an event of which one is certain: (T:) so in the saying in the Kur [xv. 2], <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّمَا يَوَدُّ ٱلَّذينَ كَفَرُوا لَوْ كَانُوا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مُسْلِمِينَ</foreign>, (T, S, M, Mughnee), meaning <hi rend="ital">Often</hi> [<hi rend="ital">will those who have disbelieved wish that they had been Muslims</hi>]; (Mughnee, Jel;) or <hi rend="ital">seldom,</hi> (Zj, T, M, Jel,) because terrors will bereave them of their reason so that they will but seldom recover reason to wish this; (Jel;) for God's threat is true, as though it had come to pass, and therefore the verb here is equivalent to a preterite [which is often used in the Kur and elsewhere in this manner]. (T.) <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> is also sometimes affixed when a noun follows, (T, Mughnee,) or a nominal proposition, and generally restricts <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign> &amp;c. from governing: thus, Aboo-Duwád says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّمَا الجَامِلُ المُؤَبَّلُ فِيهِمْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَعَنَا جِيجُ بَيْنَهُنَّ المِهَارُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Sometimes,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">often, the numerous herd of camels is among them, and</hi> there are <hi rend="ital">swift horses, among which are the colts</hi>]: another says, making <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّ</foreign>, with <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> affixed, to govern, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّمَا ضَرْبَةٍ بِسَيْفٍ صَقِيلٍ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">قَيْنِ بُصْرَى وَطَعْنَةٍ نَجْلَآءَ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Many a stroke with a polished sword of the forging of Busrà,</hi> (the Bozrah of the Bible, a city famous for its sword-blades,) <hi rend="ital">and</hi> many a <hi rend="ital">wide spear-wound;</hi> or, perhaps, <hi rend="ital">few strokes</hi> &amp;c.]: (Mughnee: [but I have substituted <foreign lang="ar">قَيْنِ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign>, which is the reading in my copy of the Mughnee, an evident mistranscription:]) and another, cited by IAar, says, <quote>
                     <L><foreign lang="ar">مَاوِىَّ يَا <ref cref="n14369-9" target="رُبَّتَمَا" n="9" type="5" subtype="TFSO" lang="ar"/>غَارَةٍ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">شَعْوَآءَ كَٱللَّذْعَةِ بِٱلْمِيسَمِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Máweeyeh,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مَاوِىَّ</foreign> being an apocopated proper name of a woman, originally <foreign lang="ar">مَاوِيَّةُ</foreign>,) <hi rend="ital">O, many a raid spreading widely and dispersedly, like the burn with the branding-iron</hi>]. (T. [In the TT, as from the T, I find, here, <foreign lang="ar">بَلْ</foreign> in the place of <foreign lang="ar">يا</foreign>, which I find in a copy of the T, and which is the reading commonly known.])    </entryFree>28:T867,<entryFree id="n14370" key="رُبٌّ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رُبٌّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Rob,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inspissated juice,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">دِبْس</foreign>,) <hi rend="ital">of any fruit;</hi> i. e., (M, TA,) the <hi rend="ital">first,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clear, juice of the thick residuum of any fruit after it has been pressed</hi> (M, K, TA) <hi rend="ital">and cooked:</hi> (M, TA:) <hi rend="ital">thick</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">طِلَآء</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">expressed juice;</hi> such as the <hi rend="ital">inspissated juice of dates,</hi> with which a skin for clarified butter is seasoned; see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph]: (S:) or <hi rend="ital">what flows from fresh ripe</hi> 
                  <pb n="1005"/> 
                  <hi rend="ital">dates, like honey, when it has been cooked</hi> [<hi rend="ital">and so rendered thick</hi>]; before which it is called <foreign lang="ar">صَقْرٌ</foreign>: (Msb in the present art. and in art. <foreign lang="ar">صقر</foreign>:) <hi rend="ital">what is prepared by coction from,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">of, dates:</hi> (TA:) <hi rend="ital">expressed juice of grapes,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">of apples, &amp;c., cooked and</hi> [<hi rend="ital">so</hi>] <hi rend="ital">thickened:</hi> (KL:) and <hi rend="ital">dregs,</hi> (K,) or <hi rend="ital">black dregs,</hi> (IDrd, M,) of clarified butter, (IDrd, M, K,) and of olive-oil: (IDrd, M:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">رُبُوبٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابٌ</foreign> (S) [and pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of <foreign lang="ar">رُبُوبٌ</foreign>) <foreign lang="ar">رُبُوبَاتٌ</foreign>, which means <hi rend="ital">sorts,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">species, of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رُبّ</foreign>]       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign>.    </entryFree>29:T9d7,<entryFree id="n14360" key="اربّ بِالمَكَانِ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">اربّ بِالمَكَانِ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (T, M, A, K, *) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِرْبَابٌ</foreign>; (T;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14360-1" target="رَبَّ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (M, K,) aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bi" lang="ar" marker="rabi3a">رَبِبَ</orth>
                  </form>; (MF, TA;) <hi rend="ital">He remained, stayed, dwelt,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abode, in the place,</hi> (T, M, A, K, *) <hi rend="ital">not quitting it;</hi> (T;) like <foreign lang="ar">أَلَبَّ</foreign>: (T, A:) and the former, [or each,] <hi rend="ital">he kept,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clave, to the place.</hi> (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">اربّتِ الإِبِلُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِالمَوْضِعِ</foreign> (T,) or <foreign lang="ar">بِمَكَانِ كَذَا</foreign>, (S,) <hi rend="ital">The camels kept,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clave,</hi> (T, S,) <hi rend="ital">to the place,</hi> (T,) or <hi rend="ital">to such a place, and remained in it.</hi> (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">اربّت النَّاقَةُ</foreign>, (S,) or <foreign lang="ar">اربّت النَاقة بِالفَحْلِ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">بِوَلَدِهَا</foreign>, (M,) <hi rend="ital">The she-camel kept to the stallion,</hi> (S, M,) and <hi rend="ital">to her young one,</hi> (M,) <hi rend="ital">and affected it.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">اربّت السَّحَابَةُ</foreign> (S, M, A) <foreign lang="ar">بِأَرْضِهِمْ</foreign> (A) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The cloud continued raining</hi> [<hi rend="ital">in their land</hi>]. (S, * M.) And <foreign lang="ar">اربّت الجَنُوبُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The south,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">southerly, wind continued.</hi> (T, S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">الإِرْبَابُ</foreign> also signifies The <hi rend="ital">drawing near,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">approaching,</hi> (S, M, K,) a thing, (S, M,) of any kind. (M.)    </entryFree>2a:T35db,<entryFree id="n14358" key="رَبَّهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رَبَّهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (M, K,) aor.     
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar" marker="rabu3a">رَبُبَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">رَبٌّ</foreign>, (M,) [<hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, its</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رَبّ</foreign>, or <hi rend="ital">lord, possessor, owner,</hi> &amp;c.;] <hi rend="ital">he possessed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">owned, it; had possession of it, and command,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">authority, over it;</hi> (M, K;) namely, a thing; (K;) syn. <foreign lang="ar">مَلَكَهُ</foreign>. (M, K.) [And in like manner, <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, his</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رَبّ</foreign>, or <hi rend="ital">lord,</hi> &amp;c.] You say, <foreign lang="ar">رَبَبْتُ القَوْمَ</foreign>, [inf. n. as above and <foreign lang="ar">مَرَبَّةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابَةٌ</foreign>,] <hi rend="ital">I ruled,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">governed, the people;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">سُسْتُهُمْ</foreign>; i. e. <hi rend="ital">I was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, over them</hi> [<hi rend="ital">as their lord, master,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chief</hi>]. (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">طَالَتْ مَرَبَّتُهُمُ النَّاسَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابَتُهُم</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Their ruling,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">governing, the people continued long.</hi> (M, K. *) The saying of Safwán, (T, S,) on the day of Honeyn, (T,) <foreign lang="ar">لَأَنْ يَرُبَّنِى رَجُلٌ مِنْ قُرَيْشٍ أَحَبُّ إِلَىَّ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ أُنْ يَرُبَّنِى رَجُلٌ مِنْ هَوَازِنَ</foreign> means [<hi rend="ital">Assuredly that a man of Kureysh</hi>] <hi rend="ital">should be over me</hi> (T, S) as <foreign lang="ar">رَبّ</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">lord,</hi> &amp;c.], and <hi rend="ital">as master,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chief, having command,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">authority, over me,</hi> (T,) [<hi rend="ital">is more pleasing to me than that a man of Hawázin should be lord,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">over me.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar" marker="rabu3a">رَبُبَ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, M,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">رَبٌّ</foreign>, (S, Mgh, M,) <hi rend="ital">He reared, fostered, brought up, fed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nourished, him; i. q.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّاهُ</foreign>; (S, M, Mgh, K;) namely, his child, (S,) or a child, (M, K,) either his own or another's; <hi rend="ital">taking good care of him, and acting as his guardian,</hi> (M,) <hi rend="ital">until he attained to puberty,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to the utmost term of youth:</hi> (M, K:) and so   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14358-1" target="ربّبهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (Lh, S, M, Mgh, K,) or this has a more emphatic signification, (TA,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَربِيبٌ</foreign> (Lh, M, Mgh, K) and <foreign lang="ar">تَرِبَّةٌ</foreign>; (Lh, M, K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14358-2" target="تربّبه" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, M, K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14358-3" target="ارتبّهُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14363"/></foreign>: (M, K:) [in like manner, also,]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14358-4" target="رَبْرَبَ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14364"/></foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">he reared, fostered,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">brought up,</hi> an orphan: (AA, T:) and accord. to IDrd, (M,) <foreign lang="ar">رَبِبْتُهُ</foreign> is a dial. var. [of <foreign lang="ar">رَبَبْٓتُهُ</foreign>]: (M, K:) he says also that the verb is used in like manner in relation to the young one of an animal other than man; and he used to cite this ex.: <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">كَانَ لَنَا وَهْوَ فَلُوٌّ نِرْبِبُهْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">He belonged to us when he was a young weaned,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">one-year-old, colt, we rearing him</hi>]; with the letter characteristic of the aor. meksoor, to show that the second letter of the preterite is meksoor, accord to the opinion of Sb in respect of a case of this kind; and this, he says, is peculiar to the dial. of Hudheyl in this species of verb. (M, TA.) <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّتِ المَرْأَةُ صَبِيَّهَا</foreign>, used tropically, means <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The woman patted her child repeatedly on its side in order that it might sleep.</hi> (A, TA.) [See 2 in art. <foreign lang="ar">ربت</foreign>.] [It is said that] the primary signification of <foreign lang="ar">الرَّبُّ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">التَّرْبِيَةُ</foreign>; i. e. The <hi rend="ital">bringing</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">to a state of completion by degrees.</hi> (Bd in i. l.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Hassán Ibn-Thábit, (TA,) <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ دُرَّةٍ بَيْضَآءَ صَافِيَةٍ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L><foreign lang="ar">مِمَّا <ref cref="n14358-5" target="تَرَبَّبَ" n="5" type="5" subtype="TFSO" lang="ar"/>حَائِرُ البَحْرِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Than a white, clear, pearl, of those which the depth of the sea has brought to maturity</hi>]; meaning a pearl which the shell has reared, or brought to maturity in the bottom of the water. (S, TA.) And the phrase <foreign lang="ar">لَكَ نِعْمَةٌ تَرُبُّهَا</foreign> occurs in a trad., meaning [<hi rend="ital">Thou hast wealth</hi>] <hi rend="ital">which thou preservest, and of which thou takest care, and which thou fosterest like as the man fosters his child.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">المَطَرُ يَرُبُّ النَّبَاتَ وَالثَّرَى</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The rain causes the plants,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">herbage, and the moisture</hi> [<hi rend="ital">of the earth</hi>] <hi rend="ital">to increase.</hi> (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">السَّحَابُ يَرُبُّ المَطَرَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The clouds collect and increase the rain.</hi> (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّ</foreign>, (T, S, M, K, TA,) aor.

                  <hi rend="ital">plant.</hi> (M, TA.)       <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14358-10" target="ربّب" n="10" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14359"/></foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">رَبَبٌ</foreign>.] You say, <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ يَرُبُّ النَّاسَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Such a one collects,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">congregates, to him the people.</hi> (T, S, M.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّ</foreign>, aor.

    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bi" lang="ar" marker="rabi3a">رَبِبَ</orth>
                  </form>, (MF, TA,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">رَبٌّ</foreign>, (M, TA,) or <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابٌ</foreign>, (S, K, [in each of which this is mentioned as the inf. n. whence the epithet <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign>,]) said of a ewe or she-goat, <hi rend="ital">She brought forth:</hi> (Lh, M, K:) <hi rend="ital">or,</hi> as some say, <hi rend="ital">she conceived:</hi> or, accord. to some, there is no verb to the epithet <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign>: (M:) AZ says that it has no verb: (Msb:) [but]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14358-11" target="رِبَابٌ" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14378"/></foreign> is an inf. n. used in relation to a ewe or she-goat as meaning her <hi rend="ital">being in the state of such as is termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign> [q. v.]: (S, M, * Msb, * K: *) and in relation to a she-camel, as in the ex. cited by Munteji' Ibn-Nebhán to As, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">حَنِينَ أُمِّ البَوِّفِى رِبَابِهَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">The yearning cry of the mother of the young camel in the time of her having recently brought forth</hi>]: (S:) and used also in relation to a woman as meaning her <hi rend="ital">having recently brought forth:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">her state within two months after having brought forth:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">within twenty days:</hi> whence the phrase, in a trad., <foreign lang="ar">حَمْلُهَا رِبَابٌ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">She becomes pregnant soon after having brought forth.</hi> (TA.)    </entryFree>2b:T458,<entryFree id="n14363" key="ارتبّهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>8</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">ارتبّهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>: see 1.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">تَرْتَبُّ الشَّعَرَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">She adjusts,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">arranges, and composes,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">collects together, the hair</hi>], said of a woman, is from [<foreign lang="ar">الرَّبُّ</foreign> signifying] <foreign lang="ar">الإِصْلَاحُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">الجَمْعُ</foreign>.                   <hi rend="ital">The grapes were cooked so as to become</hi>

                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رَبَّةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>: see <foreign lang="ar">رَبٌّ</foreign>, in three places.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">الرَّبَّةُ</foreign> was also the name of <hi rend="ital">A Kaabeh</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">square temple</hi>], (M, K,) <hi rend="ital">in Nejrán,</hi> (M,) <hi rend="ital">belonging to</hi> [<hi rend="ital">the tribe of</hi>] <hi rend="ital">Medh-hij</hi> (M, K) <hi rend="ital">and Benu-l-Hárith-Ibn-Kaab, who held it in honour.</hi> (M.) In a trad. of 'Orweh (K, TA) Ibn-Mes'ood Eth-Thakafee, (TA,) it is applied <hi rend="ital">to El-Lát</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">اللَّاتُ</foreign>), (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">the rock which</hi> [<hi rend="ital">the tribe of</hi>] <hi rend="ital">Thakeef worshipped, at Et-Táïf.</hi> (TA.) And in another trad., it is said to be the name of <hi rend="ital">A temple of</hi> [<hi rend="ital">the tribe of</hi>] <hi rend="ital">Thakeef, which, when they became Muslims, was demolished by El-Mugheereh.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّةٌ</foreign>, (K,) or <foreign lang="ar">دَارٌ رَبَّةٌ</foreign>, (M,) signifies <hi rend="ital">A large house</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mansion.</hi> (M, K.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign>.    </entryFree>2d:Td80,<entryFree id="n14372" key="رُبَّةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رُبَّةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A party, division, sect,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distinct body</hi> or <hi rend="ital">class, of men:</hi> (M:) or <hi rend="ital">a large assembly</hi> or <hi rend="ital">company:</hi> (K:) or <hi rend="ital">a myriad;</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">ten thousand:</hi> (M, K:) or <hi rend="ital">thereabout:</hi> (M:) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14372-1" target="رِبّةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies the same: (M, K:) or this signifies <hi rend="ital">a company</hi> [<hi rend="ital">of men</hi>]: (T:) the pl. of the former is <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابٌ</foreign>: (S, M:) and that of the latter is <foreign lang="ar">أَرِبَّةٌ</foreign>: (T, K:) by Th [and in the K], the former pl. is said to be a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">رِبَّةٌ</foreign>; but this is a mistake. (M.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence, the pl.] <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابٌ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">Companions.</hi> (K.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And hence [also], i. e., as pl. of <foreign lang="ar">الرُّبَةُ</foreign>, (S, M,) <foreign lang="ar">الرِّبَابُ</foreign> is an appellation of <hi rend="ital">The</hi> [<hi rend="ital">confederate</hi>] <hi rend="ital">tribes of Dabbeh;</hi> (M, K, TA;) or <hi rend="ital">Teym and 'Adee and 'Okl;</hi> (T, TA;) or <hi rend="ital">Teym and 'Adee and 'Owf and Thowr and Ashyab;</hi> (TA; [but for the orthography of the last of these names I have found no authority; it is written in the TA <foreign lang="ar">اشيب</foreign>, without any syll. signs;]) and Dabbeh was their paternal uncle; (TA;) or <hi rend="ital">five tribes which united in a confederacy, consisting of Dabbeh and Thowr and 'Okl and Teym and 'Adee:</hi> (S:) they were thus called because of their division into distinct bodies; (M;) or because they collected themselves (As, Th, S, TA) in distinct bodies: (Th, M, TA:) or because they united in a confederacy against Temeem Ibn-Murr: (AO, M, TA:) or because they dipped their hands in some <foreign lang="ar">رُبّ</foreign>, and formed a confederacy over it: (As, T, M, K:) or, as some say, because they congregated, and became like the <foreign lang="ar">رِبَاب</foreign> [or bundle] of arrows [used in the game called <foreign lang="ar">المَيْسِر</foreign>]: (TA:) the rel. n. is   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14372-2" target="رُبِّىٌّ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14389"/></foreign>, formed from the sing., (Sb, S, M,) accord. to a rule generally observed except when a [single] man has a pl. word for his name, as <foreign lang="ar">كِلَابٌ</foreign> &amp;c. (S, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  The sing. (<foreign lang="ar">رُبَّةٌ</foreign>) also signifies <hi rend="ital">Plenty,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abundance, of the means of subsistence:</hi> (K:) and <hi rend="ital">constant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inseparable, prosperity.</hi> (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign>.    </entryFree>2e:Tb0c,<entryFree id="n14373" key="رِبَّةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رِبَّةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence its pl.] <foreign lang="ar">أَرِبَّةٌ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">Confederates;</hi> (S, IB, K;) [or] it is for <foreign lang="ar">ذَوُو أَرِبَّةٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">having covenants;</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَرِبَّةٌ</foreign> being said by AAF to be pl. of <foreign lang="ar">رِبَابٌ</foreign> in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">عَهْدٌ</foreign>. (IB, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">A species of plant,</hi> (S, M, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">of the</hi> [<hi rend="ital">season called</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">صَيْف</foreign>, (M,) <hi rend="ital">remaining in the end of the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">صَيْف</foreign>: (Msb:) or the name of <hi rend="ital">a number of plants which do not dry up in the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">صَيْف</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">remaining green in the winter and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">صيف</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">summer</hi>]; <hi rend="ital">among which are the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">حُلَّب</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رُخَامَى</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَكْر</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and the</hi>

                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رُبَّانٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> The <hi rend="ital">first,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">beginning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">commencement,</hi> or the <hi rend="ital">first and fresh state,</hi> of anything; (As, A 'Obeyd, T;) [and so   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-1" target="رَبَّانٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14391"/></foreign> &amp;c., as appears from what follows.] You say, <foreign lang="ar">أَتَيْتُهُ فِى رُبَّانِ شَبَابِهِ</foreign>, (T,) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-2" target="رَبَّانِ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>شبابه</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-3" target="رِبَّانِ" n="3" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>شبابه</foreign>, (accord. to different copies of the T,) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-4" target="رُبَابِ" n="4" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>شبابه</foreign>, (T,) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-5" target="رَبَابِ" n="5" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>شبابه</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-6" target="رِبَابِ" n="6" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>شبابه</foreign>, (accord. to different copies of the T,) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-7" target="رُبَّى" n="7" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n14387"/>شبابه</foreign>, all meaning [<hi rend="ital">I came to him</hi>] <hi rend="ital">in the beginning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">first and fresh state, of his youth.</hi> (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">اِفْعَلْ ذٰلِكَ الأَمْرَ بِرُبَّانِهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Do thou that thing in its first and fresh state:</hi> so accord. to ISk: and hence, he says,   
      <foreign lang="ar">شَاةٌ <ref cref="n14392-8" target="رُبَّى" n="8" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14387"/></foreign> [explained above]. (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">أَخَذْتُ الشَّىْءَ بِرُبَّانِهِ</foreign>, (As, S, K, *) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-9" target="بِرَبَّانِهِ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, with damm and with fet-h, (K,) i. e. [<hi rend="ital">I took the thing</hi>] <hi rend="ital">in its first state:</hi> (K:) or <hi rend="ital">altogether,</hi> (As, S, K,) <hi rend="ital">not leaving of it aught.</hi> (As, S.) They said also, <foreign lang="ar">ذَرْهُ بِرُبَّانٍ</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">Leave thou him early, before he acquire more power</hi>]: and Th cites the following [as an ex.]: <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">فَذَرْهُمْ بِرُبَّانٍ وَإِلَّا تَذَرْهُمُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">يُذِيقُوكَ مَا فِيهِمْ وَإِنْ كَانَ أَكْثَرَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [which seems to mean <hi rend="ital">Then leave thou them early, before they acquire more power; for if thou do not,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wilt not, leave them, they will make thee to taste what is in them, though it be more</hi>]. (M.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also, accord. to A 'Obeyd, The <hi rend="ital">chief,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">main, part</hi> or <hi rend="ital">portion</hi> of a constellation: or, accord. to As, the <hi rend="ital">aggregate</hi> thereof: or, accord. to AO,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-10" target="رَبَّانٌ" n="10" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14391"/></foreign>, with fet-h, has this meaning: (T:) or both signify <hi rend="ital">a company</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an assembly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an aggregate</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assemblage.</hi> (K, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">A captain of sailors</hi> (Sh, K) in the sea; (Sh;) and so   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14392-11" target="رُبَّانِىٌّ" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14395"/></foreign>: (Sh, K:) <hi rend="ital">one skilled in navigation:</hi> pl. [or rather coll. n. of the latter] <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّانِيَّةٌ</foreign>. (TA voce <foreign lang="ar">رَهْنَامَجٌ</foreign>.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">رُبَّى</foreign>, in two places.    </entryFree>37:Tcde,<entryFree id="n14394" key="رَبَّانِىٌّ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">رَبَّانِىٌّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> (T, S, M, A, K) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14394-1" target="رِبِّىٌّ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14390"/></foreign> (M,) or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14394-2" target="رِبِّىٌّ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14390"/></foreign>, (A, KL,) <hi rend="ital">One who devotes himself to religious services</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exercises,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">applies himself to acts of devotion;</hi> (S, A, K;) <hi rend="ital">who possesses a knowledge of God:</hi> (T, S, K, KL:) <hi rend="ital">or a learned man:</hi> (T:) or the first signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) and so the second, (M,) <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">حَبْرٌ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">a learned man,</hi> or particularly <hi rend="ital">of the Jews,</hi> &amp;c.; or <hi rend="ital">a good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">righteous, man</hi>]; (M, K;) and <hi rend="ital">a lord,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">master, of knowledge</hi> or <hi rend="ital">science:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a worshipper of the Lord</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">الرَّبّ</foreign>): (M:) or <hi rend="ital">a learned man, a teacher of others, who nourishes people with the small matters of knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">science, before the great:</hi> (IAar, T:) or <hi rend="ital">a learned man firmly grounded in knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">science, and religion:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a learned man who practices what he knows and instructs others:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">one of high rank in knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">science:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">learned with respect to what is lawful and what is unlawful, and what is commanded and what is forbidden:</hi> (TA:) <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّانِىٌّ</foreign> is a rel. n. from <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّانٌ</foreign>; or from <foreign lang="ar">الرَّبُّ</foreign> meaning “ God: ” (TA, and some copies of the K:) the <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign> being added to give intensiveness to the signification; (M;) or, as Sb says, to denote a special reference to the knowledge of the <pb n="1007"/> Lord, as though the word signified <hi rend="ital">one possessing a knowledge of the Lord exclusively of other branches of knowledge;</hi> (T;) so that it is like <foreign lang="ar">لِحْيَانِىٌّ</foreign>, (T, M, and so in some copies of the K,) meaning “ long-bearded, ” (T,) or “ largebearded, ” (M,) and <foreign lang="ar">رَقَبَانِىٌّ</foreign>, “ thick-necked, ” and <foreign lang="ar">شَعْرَانِىٌّ</foreign>, “ having much hair: ” (T:) or it is a Syriac word; (TA, and some copies of the K;) or Hebrew; and was unknown to the [pagan] Arabs, and known only to the men of law and science: (TA:) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">رَبَّانِيُّونَ</foreign>, (T, S,) occurring in the Kur iii. 73 (S) [and v. 48 and 68].    </entryFree>38:T85b,<entryFree id="n14400" key="مَرَبٌّ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مَرَبٌّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A place of collecting</hi> (T, S, M, A) of people: (M, A:) <hi rend="ital">a place of alighting:</hi> (M, K:) <hi rend="ital">a place of abiding,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dwelling, and congregating.</hi> (M.) [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">مَرَبُّ الإِبِلِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The place where the camels keep,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remain.</hi> (T, S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence also,] <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ مَرَبٌّ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Such a one is a person who collects,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">congregates, people.</hi> (T, S, M, K. *) [And hence,] <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ مَرَبٌّ لِبَنِى فُلَانٍ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Such a one is an object of resort for his counsel and authority to the sons of such a one.</hi> (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">جمع</foreign>.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n14400-1" target="مِرْبَابٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n14405"/></foreign>, (M, K,) <hi rend="ital">Land abounding with plants,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">herbage;</hi> (K;) or with <foreign lang="ar">رِبَّة</foreign> [q. v.]: (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">land in which there ceases not to be moisture;</hi> and so

                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مُرِبٌّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> Anything <hi rend="ital">keeping,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cleaving, to a thing.</hi> (M. [See its verb, 4]) You say <foreign lang="ar">نَاقَةٌ مُرِبٌّ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A she-camel keeping to, and affecting, her young one,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the stallion.</hi> (AZ, TA.) (IAth.)    </entryFree>3a:T83d,<entryFree id="n14403" key="مُرَبَّبٌ" type="main">

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Made</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">preserved</hi>] <hi rend="ital">with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رُبّ</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">inspissated juice</hi>]; (S, K;) like as <foreign lang="ar">مُعَسَّلٌ</foreign> signifies “ made [or preserved] with <foreign lang="ar">عَسَل</foreign> [or honey]: ” (S:) you say <foreign lang="ar">زَنْجَبِيلٌ مُرَبَّبٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مُرَبًّى</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">ginger so preserved</hi>]: and
